text: Hey <@U69BL50BF> or anyone out there. Can anyone suggest the best reference or resource to understand the discretization properties of neural ODEs. Meaning if I put an ODE into a loss function, then that should not be anything new since an existing solver would just solve the ODE for the ODE component of the loss function. But if I include an NN to represent some unmodeled physics in an ODE system, then I am not sure what happens to the discretization scheme for the augmented system. I the Universal Differential Equations paper the right place to look for this, or is there a better place to get a sense of the issues or properties of these NN augmented systems.

text: Oh hey <@U69BL50BF>. I was watching the 18337 videos lecture 7 about ODE solvers, and your discussion about stability analysis for implicit methods versus I guess, explicit methods like Euler. So you talked about stiffness and timescale separation.

elements.text: . I was watching the 18337 videos lecture 7 about ODE solvers, and your discussion about stability analysis for implicit methods versus I guess, explicit methods like Euler. So you talked about stiffness and timescale separation.

text: Now in the Universal ODE paper, you talked about how we can substitute NNs into an ODE system in place of some unknown terms in the model.

elements.text: Now in the Universal ODE paper, you talked about how we can substitute NNs into an ODE system in place of some unknown terms in the model.

text: So when we add these NNs into the model, then we again need to run a solver to get the output of the system right. So then are there any new stability issues to think of, given the fact that we have NN terms?

elements.text: So when we add these NNs into the model, then we again need to run a solver to get the output of the system right. So then are there any new stability issues to think of, given the fact that we have NN terms?

text: NNs in ODEs is still new to me, so I might just be speaking gibberish. But just wondering how to examine or think about stability when there are NN terms in an equation. Like if I have NN terms in the equation, then is the only way to solve the ODE system just a training loop as in supervised learning. Or can I still solve a system like this with an implicit solver? Again, I might just be speaking gibberish, but just starting to think about these types of models.
